October 2002

NOTE

  This report was prepared by Tao Zhang, Sr. Programs Officer, SEOC.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A  Fact-Finding  Mission  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  visited  Brunei 
Darussalam,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  and  Philippines  in  September  2002  to  consult  with 
government agencies and business communities in the four countries. In the course of the 
discussions, consensus was reached on the pressing need for technical assistance (TA) to 
develop a strategic blueprint to revalidate sector/project priorities of the Brunei Darussalam, 
Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines-East ASEAN1 Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA) in response 
to  the  changing  environment  of  development  and  emerging  challenges  associated  with 
globalization.2 Understanding was also reached on the TA objectives, scope, terms of reference, 
implementation  arrangements,  and  cost  estimates.  The  TA  is  included  in  the  Subregional 
Cooperation Strategy and Program for Southeast Asia.3  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  To  promote  subregional  economic  and  trade  activities,  the  governments  of  Brunei 
Darussalam,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  and  Philippines  in  1994  formally  launched  an  economic 
cooperation initiative, BIMP-EAGA.4 The fundamental goal of BIMP-EAGA is to realize equitable 
and  sustainable  economic  development  based  on  high  value-added  agro-industry,  natural 
resources-based manufacturing, and high-grade tourism.  
3.  BIMP-EAGA was a dynamic and active subregional initiative during the early years of its 
inception.  ADB’s  early  support  for  BIMP-EAGA  was  provided  through  a  comprehensive 
investigative study prepared in 1995-1996.5 The study aimed to help mobilize the potential of 
subregional economic cooperation for the development of BIMP-EAGA, highlighting the EAGA 
profile, setting up short- and long-term development visions and strategies, and developing a 
framework for implementation and monitoring. Along with other important findings, the study 
indicated  that  there  were  “significant  investment  opportunities  based  on  latent  economic 
complementation and other forms of regional economic cooperation.” It also provided a list of 
investment and trade project proposals. 
4.  However, the implementation of the proposals in the study received a setback from the 
Asian economic crisis that began in 1997 and the El Niño phenomenon that hit most of the 
subregion in 1998. There were also changes in political leaderships and growing concerns of 
security, peace, and order in some of the BIMP-EAGA member countries. A new international 
economic situation is emerging which will have important implications for the BIMP-EAGA 
member countries. In recent years, the Southeast Asian economies, including those of BIMP-
EAGA, have witnessed a weakening of demand for their exports in major international markets. 
Amid growing intratrade and investment activities in Asia, the People’s Republic of China has 
enlarged as a major regional destination for trade and investment. Production restructuring, 
changes in consumption pattern, and technological improvement are also occurring regionwise

amid increasing globalization and growing regional economic integration in East and Southeast 
Asia.6 
5.  Improved prospects for regional cooperation and the successfully managing the risks of 
globalization are recognized as key in reviving subregional cooperation. Concerns on how 
BIMP-EAGA should respond to or adapt to the new economic environment were discussed at 
the Senior Officials Meeting held in Manado, Indonesia, on 8–9 August 2002, which called for 
immediate attention to the following two aspects.  
6.  The first is to deepen understanding of the impact of the changing global and regional 
environment on BIMP-EAGA and implications for reviving the subregional cooperation initiatives. 
The impact and implications of these changes are multidimensional. Economically, one of the 
key issues is to identify the comparative advantage of BIMP-EAGA and to exploit it for tapping a 
larger market space. On top of the policy agenda, policy parameters and incentive schemes for 
trade and investment will need to be developed and encouraged to support priority sectors and 
projects. Institution-wise, the changing context in Asia and the world imposes challenges for 
both public and private institutions in establishing a more effective partnership to facilitate factor 
and product flows and improve investor services. The role of local authorities in developing an 
enabling  environment  for  trade  and  investment  is  particularly  important,  considering  the 
deepening decentralization process in Indonesia and the Philippines.7 An updated assessment 
of EAGA’s strategic framework is needed based on a better understanding of constraints, 
prospects, and priorities in the subregion.  
7.  The second is how to prioritize the emerging opportunities for cross-border cooperation 
activities to achieve tangible results for BIMP-EAGA in a short period of time, based on the 
previous  experiences  and  clearer  understanding  of  the  prospects  of  the  subregion.  The 
prevailing  view  is  that  the  rich  potential  in  agrobusiness,  and  ecotourism  together  with 
supporting infrastructure should remain the main focus, but there is no consensus as to how to 
make it happen and where to start. To move forward, sector assessments are needed to have a 
better basis for dialogue on project-specific policy parameters and regulatory incentives. To 
improve  the  enabling  environment  for  project-based  investments  for  promoting  subregional 
economic  cooperation,  cross-border  interactions  among  concerned  public  and  private 
institutions need to be strengthened. Finally, analytical and technical inputs including identifying 
viable project opportunities, formulating project concepts, and preparing prefeasibility studies for 
selected projects or programs are also required.  
8.  Since the beginning, ADB has supported BIMP-EAGA through continuous engagement 
with the participating countries, policy dialogue, and technical assistance. In March 2002, ADB 
accepted the invitation of the ASEAN Secretariat to be the regional development advisor to 
BIMP-EAGA.  The  current  subregional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  calls  for  a  more 
vigorous support to BIMP-EAGA.8 To begin with, advisory assistance is necessary to pave the 
way for concrete project interventions and to examine the need for the required policy and 
regulatory  changes.  To  revive  BIMP-EAGA  through  enhanced  economic  activities  in  the

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
9.  The TA aims to support the participating countries in preparing a development blueprint 
for reviving and sustaining economic cooperation in BIMP-EAGA, with refocused thrusts and 
priorities in response to the changing environment and emerging challenges. The TA will assist 
in  reviewing  and  updating  EAGA’s  development  strategy  and  help  identify  achievable 
objectives, taking the investigative study (ADB. 1996. East ASEAN Growth Area: Investigative 
Study, Vol. 1, Part I, page 97 and Appendixes, Vol. 2, Part I. Manila) as a basis. The specific 
objectives  are  to  (i) enhance  understanding  of  the  strengths  and  potentials  for  economic 
cooperation among EAGA countries by reviewing changes in their production structure and 
market dynamics and policy and institutional aspects of economic cooperation in the postcrisis 
period;  (ii)  prioritize  potential  subregional  cooperation  sectors/programs/projects;  and 
(iii) support  the  preparation  and  formulation  of  project  concepts  and  prefeasibility/feasibility 
studies for selected projects or programs.   
10.  The TA output will consist of two interrelated components: (i) a status report identifying 
the current production structures and marketing network, and exploring the potential of the 
subregional initiative, to help refine the strategic role to be played by BIMP-EAGA in support of 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction;  and  determine  the  modalities  and  milestones  to 
achieve the short- and long-term objectives of BIMP-EAGA; and (ii) technical reports consisting 
of sector assessment, project conceptualization, and prefeasibility/feasibility studies for selected 
priority projects for subregional economic cooperation. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The following activities and methodologies are envisaged: 
(i)  Stakeholder consultation 
Consult with a broad spectrum of stakeholders to obtain views on development 
potentials  and  priorities,  comparative  advantages,  constraints,  and  short-  to 
medium-term prospects of BIMP-EAGA and evolve consensus on sector and 
project prioritization. 
(ii)  Research on prioritizing the strategic direction of BIMP-EAGA 
(a) Assess the impact of the changing environment on BIMP-EAGA (especially 
the growing trends of globalization and regional economic integration); 
(b) Evaluate production and marketing systems in EAGA countries in terms of 
competitiveness  and  capacity  of  the  subregion,  and  relate  them  to  the 
restructuring of production systems, changing patterns of consumption, and 
advances of technology in Asia and other parts of the world; 
(c) Identify  and  assess  changes  needed  in  national  policy  and  regulatory 
frameworks  in  trade  and  investment  for  promoting  the  private  sector 
especially small- and medium-sized enterprises;

4 
(d) Assess the role and capacities of local authorities in developing an enabling 
environment for trade and investment and in their interactions with national 
governments;  
(e) Compare and analyze the strengths and weaknesses of different groupings of 
BIMP-EAGA  countries  in  terms  of  their  economic  structure  to  provide  a 
conceptual  basis  for  strengthening  bilateral  and  multilateral  economic 
cooperation; and  
(f)  Suggest  modalities  and  identify  milestones  to  achieve  the  short-  and 
long-term objectives of BIMP-EAGA. 
 
(iii)  Review and revalidate sector priorities and conceptualize investment projects  
(a) Review the past performance in project preparation and implementation for 
subregional projects, based primarily on the 1996 investigative study (ADB. 
1996. East ASEAN Growth Area: Investigative Study, Appendixes, Vol. 2, 
Part I. Manila); 
(b) Assess the development needs of priority sectors and formulate an approach 
to subregional cooperation in these sectors; 
(c) Identify and prioritize potential subregional projects in the selected sectors, 
based on the updated strategic development framework of BIMP-EAGA; 
(d) Prepare  project  concepts  and  prefeasibility/feasibility  studies  for  selected 
projects or programs.  
 
(iv)  Support implementation of the prioritized strategic plans and project proposals in 
selected sectors  
(a) Conduct  consultative  meetings  with  representatives  of  implementing 
agencies of BIMP-EAGA under the current institutional framework; 
(b) Through  appropriate  mechanism/forums,  build  consensus  among  the 
participating countries on priority sectors and sector development strategies; 
and 
(c) Assist in developing implementing plans for high priority project proposals. 
(v)  Provide training and disseminate information  
(a) Organize  training  seminars  involving  policy  makers,  representatives  of 
business communities, and research workers for awareness of the TA and 
required changes in policies and regulations, and to exchange views on best 
practice and lessons learned; and 
(b) Disseminate the major findings and output of the TA. 
 
12.  While Brunei Darussalam is not currently an ADB member, the RETA includes Brunei 
Darussalam as its participation is essential for the objective of the TA to help promote BIMP-
EAGA. 
C.  Cost and Financing  
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 is foreign exchange 
cost  and  $100,000  equivalent  is  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  finance  the  entire  foreign 
exchange  cost  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  four  participating 
countries will share the remaining local costs of $100,000 equivalent by providing office space, 
staff support, and other in-kind contributions. The TA will cover the costs of engaging consulting 
services (remuneration, per diem, and travel) and preparing study reports. The TA will also 
finance in-country seminars and workshops for capacity building and dissemination of major TA

5
findings  and  output.  As  currently  Brunei  Darussalam  is  not  an  ADB  member,  Brunei 
Darussalam's contribution will include all direct local costs related to the implementation of the 
TA in Brunei Darussalam, excluding the expenses related to the consulting services. Brunei 
Darussalam will also finance its participation in meetings and workshops. The detailed cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA.  With  the  assistance  of  a  team  of 
consultants, ADB staff will work with the government agencies, business communities, and 
research institutions in implementing the TA. The TA will be implemented over 10 months 
commencing  January  2003,  with  completion  in  October  2003.  The  TA  requires  consulting 
services of 24 person-months to be provided by a consulting firm. The firm will be responsible 
for the overall conduct of the TA, including providing the services of 3 international (12 person-
months) and 4 domestic consultants (12 person-months). The outline terms of references for 
consultants is in Appendix 3. The consulting firm will be recruited by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants, using the simplified technical proposals procedures under ADB’s quality 
cost based system. Policy dialogue and consultation will be carried out with public institutions, 
private sector, as well as other aid agencies. Concerned government agencies of BIMP-EAGA 
will provide logistic convenience and support including liaising with the consultant team and 
assisting to access required information and data. All procurement of equipment and materials, 
and service payments under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s requirements. 
15.  The consultant team will submit an inception report to ADB within 2 weeks of the start of 
services. The inception report will (i) focus on initial assessment and prepare a realistic plan for 
subsequent actions to ensure that the required TA outputs are completed on time; and (ii) make 
adjustments, as appropriate, in other key issues affecting the realization of the TA objectives, 
which are to be identified through consultation with government agencies and representatives of 
business  communities.  Draft  final  reports  (position  report  and  technical  reports)  by  the 
consultant team will be completed in April 2003.9 Consultative meetings and training seminars 
will  be  conducted  during  TA  implementation.  Training  materials  will  also  be  prepared  as 
required. The final TA reports will be completed in August 2003. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Prioritizing Strategic Directions for BIMP-EAGA, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
9  The draft final report is expected to be available for discussion and consultation during the next BIMP-EAGA Senior 
Officials Meeting scheduled for April/May 2003.

TERMS OF REFERENCE 
A.  Project Director/Regional Cooperation Advisor 
(International consultant: 4.5 person-months, spread over 10 calendar months) 
1.  The  project  director/regional  cooperation  advisor  will  coordinate,  advise  on  overall 
technical assistance (TA) implementation, and be responsible for preparing the overall TA 
reports. The advisor, preferably with experience in Southeast Asia, will have knowledge and 
expertise in regional and subregional economic cooperation matters, development economics 
especially trade and investment, and private sector development. Sector knowledge in either 
agrobusiness, infrastructure, or ecotourism is also required.  
2.  The responsibilities will include the following: 
(i)  Take a lead role in coordination within the TA consultant team, and between the 
TA consultant team and the concerned stakeholders;  
(ii)  Advise on TA-related issues; 
(iii)  Undertake field visits to participating countries to (a) lead consultative meetings 
assessing  the  opportunities,  constraints,  and  prospects  for  subregional 
cooperation in BIMP-EAGA; and (b) conduct training seminars on awareness of 
trade and investment parameters; 
(iv)  Provide a literature review on regional and subregional economic cooperation, 
emphasizing growth areas/triangles in Asia and the Pacific region; 
(v)  Identify key factors that explain the past performance of BIMP-EAGA in terms of 
economic growth and economic cooperation, highlighting the salient features of 
BIMP-EAGA compared with other subregional cooperation initiatives (including 
growth triangles or areas) in the Asia and Pacific region;10 
(vi)  Based  on  inputs  from  other  members  of  the  consultant  team,  prepare  an 
inception report highlighting approach, work plan, and schedules for field visits; 
(vii)  Consult  with  other  members  of  the  consultant  team  and  conduct  project 
implementation briefing on a semimonthly basis; 
(viii)  Undertake research on the impact of a changing global and regional context on 
BIMP-EAGA  and  its  implications  for  reviving  the  subregional  cooperation 
initiatives (to be delivered as a position report); and  
(ix)  Together with other members of the consultant team, prepare the final TA reports, 
summarizing  major  findings  with  appended  technical  reports,  including 
recommendations  on  policy  and  institutional  reforms  and  key  milestones  for 
achieving the revised BIMP-EAGA objectives.

B.  Sector Experts 
(International  consultants:  3  persons  of  2.5  person-months  each,  spread  over 
10 calendar months) 
3.  Three  sector  experts  preferably  with  expertise  in  agrobusiness,  infrastructure,  and 
ecotourism, and regional experiences in Southeast Asia will provide advisory and technical 
services in selected sectors. They will undertake the following activities: 
(i)  Make  field  visits  to  participating  countries  to  (a)  facilitate  and  participate  in 
consultative  meetings  and  in  assessing  and  reviewing  viable  investment 
opportunities and constraints in the selected priority sectors; and (b) conduct and 
participate in training seminars to build the capacity for business networking and 
create awareness of trade and investment parameters; 
(ii)  From the field research and the findings of the position report, prepare technical 
reports assessing the development needs of priority sectors and formulating 
approaches to regional cooperation in these sectors, including a prioritized list of 
potential subregional projects/programs; 
(iii)  Develop  project  profiles  (prefeasibility  studies)  for  selected  high-priority 
projects/programs;  
(iv)  Assist in developing an implementing plan for high-priority project proposals, 
including suggestions for appropriate mechanisms/framework for cross-border 
coordination in project implementation;  
(v)  Prepare  technical  reports  consisting  of  sector  assessment,  project 
conceptualization,  and  prefeasibility/feasibility  studies  for  selected  priority 
projects; and 
(vi)  Provide technical support as required by the project director. 
4.  The sector experts will report to the project director and ADB’s project officer of the TA, 
and work closely with BIMP-EAGA counterparts including private sector representatives.
